to party unity and party success.

of Acclimated and West Virginia Horses, Colts ana
Mules, on Saturday, February 16, 1918, at 1 o'Clock

We will sell one carload of West Virgiuia
Horses and Colts, consisting of good, big, rug-
ged feeders, all-purpose horses, farm chunks
and fancy driving horses and colts ranging in
age from 3 to 6 years and have them weigh-
ing up to 1600 pounds cach. This is posi-
tively one of the best loads of horses and colts
all through, that we have had out of Virginia
in a long time, each and every one a good one,
with class, shape, size, weight, quality all over.
Thirty head of acclimated horses of all de-
scriptions, Twenty head of mules of all kinds.

P. S.—We expect J. E. Martin to arrive by Saturday with an
express load of Missouri mules. He says the best load he ever shipped

river on both its branches. This

He was connected with the R,
Graupner Brewery. He had been
ill health for the last few years,
was confined to‘his bed since
afternoon. He survived
mother, Mrs I,
sister, Mrs. E. W, Long,
brothers, Max R. Graupner,
Graupner and IFrred W.
all of this city.

Private funeral services will be held
at the home Saturday, the Rev. Rein-
hold Schmidt, of St.
Lutheran Church, officiating.
will be made in the Paxtang
tery.

Frederick Graupner,
the deceased man, was quietly
ried this morning to Miss Mae
Stcelton, in Philadelphia.

James Curtis Weirick, 54, died at his
late residence, 347 South Fifteenth
street, this morning. Funeral services
will be held to-morrow morning, at 9
o'clock, at his residence, the Rev. Dr.
A. Lyter, pastor of the Derry Street
nited Brethren Church, officiating.
urther services will be held at the
lutheran Church in Liverpool, Sunday
afternoon, at 2 o’clock. Burial wili
be made in the Liverpool Cemetery.
The body may be viewed this evening
from 7 to 9 o'clock.

Mr. Weirick is survived by his wife,
Bessie Weirick, and two brothers, T.
KE. Weirick, Liverpool, and H. “
Weirick, of this city.

Mr. Weirick was a retired butcher,
formerly from Liverpool.

William H, Hoofnagle, 73, died to-
ady, at his home, in Penbrook. Funeral
services will be held Saturday after-
noon, at 2 o'clock, the Rev. Mr. Mil-
ler, pastor of the United Brethren
Church, of Penbrook, officiating.
Burial will be made in the Penbrook
Cemetery. ¢ is survived by his wife,
two daughters, Mrs. John Nissley and
Miss Susan Hoofnagle; a son, Donald
Hoofvagie. and a grandson.

The principal address
morning session was made by James |
Neal, chief of the agricultural boil-|
er inspectors, of the Department of |
Labor and Industry, who declared
his bureau was handicapped last
year in the work of inspecting trac-
tion engines boilers by the difficulty
in securing a sufficient number of
competent county inspectors, He
asked further co-operation of the
Threshermen's Association in gett-
ing more inspectors this year and
inv getting the work started earlier
than in 1917

Jacob A, treasurer of the!
‘association, submitted his annual re-
port that showed a total of $3,943.:
receipts in the year ended February
, 1, which added to a balance of $1,-
033.20 from the previous year, made
a total of $4,976.52, from which were}
ceducted last year $4,285.17, in-
cluding surplus funds deposited in
banks and $900 invested in Liberty
Bonds. The balance February 1,
Was $691.35 which, with the funds
on: deposit in bank and invested in
Liberty Bonds, made the total bal-
ance of the association $2,645.07.

J. Denny O'Neil, State Highway
Commissioner, in his address last
night declared the state had made
a mistake in taking over 11,060 miles
of highway at one time. He advo-
cated taking over only such parts}
could be permanently improved.
Among the speakers were John A,
MecSparren, master of the State
Grange; William T. Creasy, of Cata-
wissa, and Gabriel Moyer, deputy
auditor general.

MRS. CATHERINE H. HEARN
Funeral services for Mrs. Catherine
Hearn, 77, will be held this evening
the residence of her daughter, Mrs.
H. Bruce, 2003 North Sixth street,
the Rev, Amos M. Stamets, pastor of |
the Augsburg Lutheran Church, of-!
ficiating. Further and burial
will be at Huntingdon to-morrow
morning. Mrs, Hearn died at the
thome of her daughter, Mrs. William
Dysard, 3222 North Sixth street, Tues-
afternoon. A son and two daugh-|

West Fairview w Woman
Dies at Advanced Age

West Fairviow, Feb. 14.—Mrs. H. |
D. Musser died at West Fairview,
yesterday afternoon. Funeral serv-
ices will be held in the United Breth-
ren Church, Monday afternoon at
1.30 o'clock.

She was the mother of Harry C.
Musser, Corinth, Miss., and Charles
|E. Musser, of West Fairview. She is |
also survived by her husband and |
the following grandchildren: Mrs.
Jennie Loper, Ella Hummel, Camp
Hill; Warren Musser, Philadelphia;
Virgie Musser, Maizie Musser, Har-
risburg, and Ida Warren and Wil-
liam Musser, West Fairview,

20 ‘HOURS IN AMBULANCE .
WITH BODY OF DEAD MAN

Hammond, Ind.—-The most. grew-
some story of the blizzard’s after-
math comes from Lansing, two miles
north of here. W. H. Sweat, super-
intendent of the Lansing Brick Com-
pany, fell dead from shoveling snow,
John Kueger was engaged to take
the body by motor ambulance to
Blue Island.

The motor stalled in the snow-
drifts and for twenty hours while
the blizzard raged, Kueger was com-
pelled to seek refuge inside the am-
bulance with the dead body before
relief came to him. He had to take
the covering off the dead bedy to
keep himself alive,

The efforts of Harrisburg Hebrews |
to raise $15,000 for their war relief
fund and welfare work are meeting |
with the approval of «itizens gen-|
erally. |

The Jewish board welfare |
work has organized L the ap-
proval of the Secretary of War for
the purpose of doing among the
60,000 Jews in the Army and Navy'
the same kind of work as Mn oon |
among protestants by the Y. M.
c. A. and among Catholics by the|
Knights of Columbus.

There are eighty-three camps or
stations in the United States, sixteen |
national Army cantonments, sixteen |
National Guard camps, twelve offi-
eers training camps, ore canton-|
ment at embarkation point. In ad-|}
dition to this there are the men|
abroad in whose behalf co- -operation |
has been secured from the Jews of
France through the Alliance Israel-}
ite Universelle. At perhaps all of
camps it will be necessary for|
the board to supply camp secretar- |
ies who are competent to look after,
the needs of each individual Jew-|
ish soldier as these needs arise. Large}
numbers of the Jewish soldiers are
unable to speak English and must be)
handled by workers .who can reach
them in Yiddish.
But as is true with the Y.

|
M. A. |
suits" |
in the training camps, the Jewish |
“huts” are open to all soldiers and |
sailors, no matter what their creeds|
or lack of creeds may be.
The local campaign opens Tues-
day morning, and will continue
Tuesday, Wednesday and Thurs-

at any point along
the line other than in the French
sector they are holding—
an indeterminate stretch east of St.
Mihiel. The assumption is that the
American artillerymen mentioned
are part of the numbers undergoing
by the French before
taking up the task of supporting
their own infantry.

The Butte Du Mesnil, near which
the raid was carried out, lies in the
area in which the great French of-
fensive of 1915 took place, It is
some two miles northeast of the
town of Le Mesnil-Lez-Hurlus and
slightly less than that distance
goutheast of Tahure.

Berlin's official report to-day con-
eedes a French success in the raid
near that place, admitting that a
footing was secured by Petain’s
troops in a salient of the German
positions. Paris announces the tak-
ing of more than 150 prisoners in
the operation, which was carried
out on a front of about two-thirds
of a mile, and reports the positions
taken have been organized.

Three Wills Probated.—The fol-
wills were probated to-day
and letters testamentary issued by
Register Roy C. Danner. William
F, Darby, of Steelton, widely-known
attorney, letters to Bertha Darby;
Benton S. Bowman, Millersburg, let-
ters to George M. Bowman; Mrs.
Marie Mester, city, letters to George
Gottwalt and George W. Liesmann.

Elect Trustees.—cCreditors of the
Sicier Piano Company, adjudicated
a bankruptcy January 30, met yes-
terday afternoon at the office of
John T. Olmsted and elected Job J.
Conklin trustee, fixing his bond at
$25,000.

PASSENGERS HURT WHEN
TROLLEY CARS COLLIDE
—
Passengers in a Reservoir car
terday afternoon received a shaking-
up in a rear-end collision. Two re-
ceived injuries, Others had a nar-
row escape from being cut by the
flying Car No. 65, en route
east on Market street, hit a Middle-
town car that was standing at Third
and Market streets. The Reservoir
was damaged on the front end
and was sent to the barn for repairs.
The injured were able to go to their
homes, Passengers were transferred
to another car at Cameron and Mar-
ket streets.
